studies.study_name: Main Study: Anchoring in Quantitative Estimation
hypotheses: The initial judgment of the anchor is susceptible to an anchoring-like bias.
The anchoring effect is larger for high anchors than for low anchors (asymmetry).
The anchoring effect varies inversely with subjects' confidence.
Susceptibility to anchoring is associated with low confidence.
Highly confident subjects are not immune to anchoring, though the effect is smaller.

sub_studies.content: A calibration group provided estimates and confidence ratings for 15 uncertain quantities to establish baseline distributions and anchors (15th and 85th percentiles).

participants.description: Students at the University of California, Berkeley.

items.text: Amount of meat eaten per year by average American (in pounds)
Distance from San Francisco to New York City (in miles)
Number of female professors at the University of California, Berkeley
Average number of babies born per day in the United States
Maximum speed of house cat (in miles per hour)
Amount of gas used per month by average American (in gallons)
Number of bars in Berkeley, CA
Number of state colleges and universities in California

sub_studies.content: Participants performed two tasks for each of 15 quantities: 1) Judged if the quantity was higher or lower than a specified anchor. 2) Estimated the quantity and rated their confidence on a 10-point scale.

participants.description: Students at the University of California, Berkeley.

statistical_results.claim: The subject moved almost halfway toward the anchor from the estimate they would have made without it.
Measure of the size of the effect: correlation between subjects' estimates and the anchor seen.
The effect of high anchors (median transformed score = 76) was significantly larger than for low anchors (median = 36).
statistical_results.location: Page 1163, Effects of High and Low Anchors

statistical_results.claim: High anchors yielded 27% extreme estimates (beyond anchor) compared to 14% for low anchors.
Correlation between the AI and the mean confidence in the calibration group across 15 problems.
Negative correlation (mean r = -.14) between transformed estimates and confidence when anchor is high.
Positive correlation (mean r = .27) between transformed estimates and confidence when anchor is low.
Estimates were made with greater confidence in anchored groups (3.85) than in calibration group (2.99).

hypotheses: Discrediting the informational value of the anchor will not reduce the anchoring effect.

sub_studies.content: A close replication of Exp 1 using the same problems but with an added manipulation intended to discredit the informational value of the anchor.

participants.description: Not specified, implied similar to Exp 1 population.

statistical_results.statistic: High judged low: 28%; Low judged high: 15%
statistical_results.claim: The manipulation of credibility did not reduce the anchoring effect.

studies.study_name: Anchoring in Estimation vs. Willingness to Pay (WTP)
hypotheses: Anchoring effects occur in Willingness to Pay (WTP) tasks as they do in estimation tasks.

sub_studies.content: Compared anchoring in 3 estimation problems and 2 WTP questions for public goods. Subjects made dichotomous judgments (referendum for WTP) before numerical estimates.

participants.description: Referenced from Green, Jacowitz, Kahneman, & McFadden (1995).

statistical_results.statistic: High anchors: 24% equaled or exceeded highest anchor (vs 4.2% calibration); Low anchor: 15% judged high (vs 4.6% calibration).
statistical_results.claim: High anchors yielded a large proportion of answers even higher than the anchor.

paper_title: Measures of Anchoring in Estimation Tasks
paper_abstract: The authors describe a method for the quantitative study of anchoring effects in estimation tasks. A calibration group provides estimates of a set of uncertain quantities. Subjects in the anchored condition first judge whether a specified number (the anchor) is higher or lower than the true value before estimating each quantity. The anchors are set at predetermined percentiles of the distribution of estimates in the calibration group (15th and 85th percentiles in this study). This procedure permits the transformation of anchored estimates into percentiles in the calibration group, allows pooling of results across problems, and provides a natural measure of the size of the effect. The authors illustrate the method by a demonstration that the initial judgment of the anchor is susceptible to an anchoring-like bias and by an analysis of the relation between anchoring and subjective confidence.
